A **mace** is a type of [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a one-handed melee weapon that is made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron").

The mace is the [base item](/wiki/Base_item "Base item") for the [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") [The Sceptre of Might](/wiki/The_Sceptre_of_Might "The Sceptre of Might").

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit b1a5a9c3](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/b1a5a9c3903a0282f82787d20fd70f13196e2465), [Demonbane](/wiki/Demonbane "Demonbane")'s base item is changed to a mace.

## Generation

Maces make up about 4% of randomly generated weapons (on the floor, as [death drops](/wiki/Death_drop "Death drop"), or in [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop")).

[Priests](/wiki/Priest "Priest") start each game with a [blessed](/wiki/Blessed "Blessed") [+1](/wiki/Enchantment "Enchantment") mace.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

[Aligned priests](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest") and [high priests](/wiki/High_priest "High priest") are [always generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") maces, that are enchanted from +1 to +3 and have a 1⁄2 chance of being cursed.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) [Sergeants](/wiki/Sergeant "Sergeant") in the [Yendorian army](/wiki/Yendorian_army "Yendorian army") have a 1⁄2 chance of generating with a mace.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

One of the weapons guarded by the [ghost](/wiki/Ghost "Ghost") on the [Rogue level](/wiki/Rogue_level "Rogue level") has a 1⁄2 chance of being a mace, with an enchantment ranging from +0 to +3 and a 3⁄4 chance of being [cursed](/wiki/Cursed "Cursed")[\[4\]](#cite_note-4) - the mace is the starting weapon for the player character in *[Rogue](/wiki/Rogue_\(game\) "Rogue (game)")*.

[Player monsters](/wiki/Player_monster "Player monster") generated on the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane") have a 1⁄29 chance (effectively \~3.45%) of generating with a mace as their weapon before role-based replacements.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5) Player monsters [priests](/wiki/Priest_\(player_monster\) "Priest (player monster)") have a 1⁄2 chance of forcing a mace as their weapon, resulting in an effective \~50.86% chance of generating with one, while player monster [cavepeople](/wiki/Caveman_\(player_monster\) "Caveman (player monster)") have a 3⁄4 chance of forcing a mace, raising their effective chance to \~75.43%.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)

## Mace skill

| Mace    |                                                                                                           |
| ------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Max     | [Role](/wiki/Role "Role")                                                                                 |
| Basic   | - [Healer](/wiki/Healer "Healer"), [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist"), [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard")    |
| Skilled | * [Barbarian](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian"), [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight"), [Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue") |
| Expert  | - [Caveman](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman"), [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest")                                     |

The mace is the only weapon to use the **mace [skill](/wiki/Skill "Skill")**.

## Strategy

The mace is generally an unimpressive weapon, though the starting +1 mace for Priests is at least passable. It is typically worth exchanging for a more versatile weapon, such as a [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword") or [aklys](/wiki/Aklys "Aklys").

## History

The mace first appears in Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, which are based on [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"), and is included in the initial item list for [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Mace (bludgeon)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mace_\(bludgeon\) "wikipedia:Mace (bludgeon)")***

A mace is type of blunt club or rod that uses a heavy head on the end of a strong and heavy shaft to deliver powerful strikes; it also comes in a two-handed variety and is typically made of stone, bone, copper, bronze, iron, steel, or even metal-reinforced wood. Military maces can be shaped with flanges or knobs to allow greater penetration of plate armour, with their length depending on the soldier's rank.

Maces are used throughout prehistory and post-classical history, and in the modern era are rarely used for actual combat; ceremonial maces are still kept by many universities, government bodies such as the British House of Commons and the U.S. Congress, and other institutions to display as symbols of authority.

The mace's use as a standard weapon for priesthood is derived from *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, where clerical classes are typically forbidden by their god from shedding blood with edged weapons.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

[SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") adds the [silver mace](/wiki/Silver_mace "Silver mace") as a weapon that uses the mace skill, and introduces another artifact mace in [Disrupter](/wiki/Disrupter "Disrupter").

### SporkHack

[SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack") adds the silver mace as a weapon that uses the mace skill, though it exists only as the base item for [Demonbane](/wiki/Demonbane "Demonbane").

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), the mace deals 1d10+1 damage to small monsters and 1d10 to large monsters. Both variants add the [elven mace](/index.php?title=Elven_mace\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Elven mace (page does not exist)") and [kamerel vajra](/wiki/Kamerel_vajra "Kamerel vajra") as weapons that use the mace skill.

Some artifacts use the mace skill in some manner:

- [The Rod of Lordly Might](/wiki/The_Rod_of_Lordly_Might "The Rod of Lordly Might") and [The Rod of the Elvish Lords](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#The_Rod_of_the_Elvish_Lords "DNetHack artifacts") are artifacts that can take on the form of a mace or elven mace, respectively.
- The [Rod of the Ram](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Rod_of_the_Ram "DNetHack artifacts") is a neutral mace.
- The [Field Marshal's Baton](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Field_Marshal.27s_Baton "DNetHack artifacts") is a lawful mace.
- The [Rod of Dis](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Rod_of_Dis "DNetHack artifacts") is a lawful intelligent mace wielded by [Dispater](/wiki/Dispater "Dispater").
- [The Wand of Orcus](/wiki/The_Wand_of_Orcus_\(dNetHack\) "The Wand of Orcus (dNetHack)") uses the mace skill when wielded and used as a melee weapon.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), the mace that an aligned priest generates with is never created cursed.

Demonbane's base item is changed to a mace made of [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver"), similar to SporkHack.

### SpliceHack

[SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack") adds the [executioner's mace](/wiki/Executioner%27s_mace "Executioner's mace") and [ornate mace](/wiki/Ornate_mace_\(SpliceHack\) "Ornate mace (SpliceHack)") as weapons that use the mace skill.

### EvilHack

[EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") adds the [heavy mace](/wiki/Heavy_mace "Heavy mace"), [rod](/wiki/Rod "Rod"), [dark elven mace](/wiki/Dark_elven_mace "Dark elven mace"), and [dark elven heavy mace](/wiki/Dark_elven_heavy_mace "Dark elven heavy mace") as weapons that use the mace skill. A few artifacts use the mace skill as well:

- Demonbane (heavy mace)
- The Scepter of Might (rod)
- [Wand of Orcus](/wiki/Wand_of_Orcus_\(EvilHack\) "Wand of Orcus (EvilHack)") (rod)

A mace can be created at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") by combining a [dagger](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger") and a [club](/wiki/Club "Club"). Maces can be used to create many other items:

- Two maces can be combined to create a heavy mace.
- A mace can be combined with 2 [rubies](/wiki/Rubies "Rubies") to create a rod.
- A mace can be combined with a dagger to create a [morning star](/wiki/Morning_star "Morning star").
- A mace can be combined with an [orcish dagger](/wiki/Orcish_dagger "Orcish dagger") to create a [orcish morning star](/wiki/Orcish_morning_star "Orcish morning star").
- A mace can be combined with a [flail](/wiki/Flail "Flail") to create a [war hammer](/wiki/War_hammer "War hammer").
- A mace can be combined with a [helmet](/wiki/Helmet "Helmet") to create [gauntlets](/wiki/Gauntlets_\(EvilHack\) "Gauntlets (EvilHack)").

### SlashTHEM

In addition to SLASH'EM details, [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") adds the ornate mace as a weapon that uses the mace skill.

### Hack'EM

[Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM") adds the executioner's mace from SpliceHack and the heavy mace and rod from EvilHack as weapons that use the mace skill.

The base item of the Sceptre of Might is changed to an executioner's mace.

## Encyclopedia entry

Originally a club armed with iron, and used in war; now a staff  
of office pertaining to certain dignitaries, as the Speaker of  
the House of Commons, Lord Mayors, Mayors etc. Both sword and  
mace are symbols of dignity, suited to the times when men went  
about in armour, and sovereigns needed champions to vindicate  
their rights.

\[ Brewer's Concise Dictionary of Phrase and Fable ]

* [[The Wand of Orcus (dNetHack)|The Wand of Orcus]] uses the mace skill when wielded and used as a melee weapon.

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], the mace that an aligned priest generates with is never created cursed.

Demonbane's base item is changed to a mace made of [[silver]], similar to SporkHack.

===SpliceHack===
[[SpliceHack]] adds the [[executioner's mace]] and [[Ornate mace (SpliceHack)|ornate mace]] as weapons that use the mace skill.

===EvilHack===
[[EvilHack]] adds the [[heavy mace]], [[rod]], [[dark elven mace]], and [[dark elven heavy mace]] as weapons that use the mace skill. A few artifacts use the mace skill as well:

* Demonbane (heavy mace)
* The Scepter of Might (rod)
* [[Wand of Orcus (EvilHack)|Wand of Orcus]] (rod)

A mace can be created at a [[Forge (dungeon feature)|forge]] by combining a [[dagger]] and a [[club]]. Maces can be used to create many other items:

* Two maces can be combined to create a heavy mace.
* A mace can be combined with 2 [[rubies]] to create a rod.
* A mace can be combined with a dagger to create a [[morning star]].
* A mace can be combined with an [[orcish dagger]] to create a [[orcish morning star]].
* A mace can be combined with a [[flail]] to create a [[war hammer]].
* A mace can be combined with a [[helmet]] to create [[Gauntlets (EvilHack)|gauntlets]].

===SlashTHEM===
In addition to SLASH'EM details, [[SlashTHEM]] adds the ornate mace as a weapon that uses the mace skill.

===Hack'EM===
[[Hack'EM]] adds the executioner's mace from SpliceHack and the heavy mace and rod from EvilHack as weapons that use the mace skill.

The base item of the Sceptre of Might is changed to an executioner's mace.
